body: Maybe related to #15506 ?
We are using ChannelCredentials.Insecure. so that probably doesn't apply

We are working on adding a built-in retry support for the grpc stack (if configured properly, your calls will get automatically retried by grpc library if they fail with a retriable status).  @markdroth   what is the status of the retry support?

Alternatively, you can implement the retry support yourself in your client code.
@jtattermusch if I would do retry myself can I do it in single place or do I have to wrap every call I make with try/catch?

I am also having this issue, although I get it 100% of the time. I'm redoing the project from scratch to see if it's easily reproduced.
This is on Windows 10, also with ChannelCredentials.Insecure,

The core of the retry functionality is implemented, but there are still some problems with it, and we've had to put the remainder of that work on the back burner temporarily due to other priorities.  I would suggest not relying on it until we have time to finish the work.

Btw why does disconnected connection give StatusCode.Unknown and not something like StatusCode.Unavailable?

If I only want to retry "Stream removed" (try/catch) is it safe to rely on that "Stream removed" text?
@wanton7   you can implement retries in single place using the recently-introduced C# interceptors functionality: https://github.com/grpc/proposal/blob/master/L12-csharp-interceptors.md

Hi, we also started to get these errors in the last few days.
We're using Spanner and sometimes queries gets these RpcException "Stream removed" errors. 
Please advise, thanks.

Update - we had an high CPU issue in the VM which probably helped this exception to be thrown frequently. After eliminating the CPU hog - we didn't see it (yet). But it still rarely happen also in other 'normal' VM's.

For the record, we have seen this reports of this on the Python side as well which I originally attributed to retries but I have some doubts that this might be an additional bug. It'd be great for someone from core who knows the expected semantics as implemented today should weigh in (I had expected UNAVAILABLE, as opposed to other status codes, UNKNOWN in the following case, for the expected failure case): https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50689396/grpc-python-how-to-add-idle-time-for-client

@jtattermusch 

Hi Jan!
You mentioned building a retry interceptor. I was trying to make one but hit a snag. Trying to mark the AsyncUnaryCall interceptor override as async (so I can await the call and catch resulting errors) seems like it should work because AsyncUnaryCall implements GetAwaiter - but I get this error when building instead:

      Error	CS1983	The return type of an async method must be void, Task or Task<T>

As far as I can tell, this is because the class also needs to have an AsyncMethodBuilder specified. Is this something that just needs fixing, or is there some other way to achieve what I want via interceptors? (be able to catch the error, inspect it for retry-ableness, and retry or fail accordingly)?

And as a side question, will this future retry layer handle "GOAWAY received" errors?

@vadimi 

Thanks!! This helped us get something that we think seems to be working - we're still playing around with it. We made one change near the end - we replaced the responseAsync.Result call with a responseasync.Unwrap() to avoid blocking there for the result. Thanks for sharing!
I've also faced this exact bug. The client is xunit test written in C#, running on Windows 10. The server is .NET Core 2.0 (also C#) running in docker container based on debian distro of linux.

@simonz130  @vadimi @Wisgary @shlomiw
Can anyone provide a simple reproduction?

It’s hard to provide a simple reproduction, but here is my setup. I run gRPC services in AWS and I have a Network Load Balancer (basically L4) between my client and service. NLB has 350 second IDLE timeout, right after that timeout with no active RPCs connection gets terminated by NLB and I get “Stream removed” exception. Immediate retry solves it, but it’s unclear why the error code is Unknown, but not Unavailable, so handling this retry requires some additional logic.
I suspect that in my case it could have been because there were two different processes listening on the same port. When killing one of the processes, things looked better.
I was having the same problem. In my case my server was listening to localhost instead of 0.0.0.0. Not really related to this issue I think.

I am having the same problem. In my case, I tried published [example written in C#](https://grpc.io/docs/quickstart/csharp.html#using-visual-studio-xamarin-studio-or-mondevelop-ides)(I cloned the repository, built `GreeterServer` and `GreeterClient` and ran them.) and then the `GreeterClient` throwed the above exception.

my environment is bellows:

* using C# 
* using Visual Studio 2017
* grpc version is 1.13.1
@ricardopieper Thank you so much. That was my issue too.

Hi all, I spent some time trying to reproduce the problem without success. Additional information would be helpful from those able to reproduce:
- please include there exact exception thrown (this issue is only about "StatusCode=Unknown Detail="Stream removed")
- the flakiness rate you are observing (it looks like this is happening only occasionally)
- is your use case accessing Google APIs or are you accessing your own server (in case it's your own server, please include info about network topology, is there a proxy?). Are you using a plain gRPC library or a google api client library built on top of gRPC?
- what's your platform (it seems like this might be happening mostly with Windows 10 clients, but the data is very unclear).
- what is gRPC C# version you are using?
- when possible, please include additional trace logs (see https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/TROUBLESHOOTING.md) for instructions.

FTR, the only place in C core code where "Stream removed" error is coming from is here:
https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/fe431b4d8ad24c2fc9981f4b9fc28ab75020c410/src/core/ext/transport/chttp2/transport/chttp2_transport.cc#L2226
I also went through the log of recent windows unit test failures and didn't see the "Stream removed" problem anywhere.

I was using plain C# library for both client and server. Both client and server where running in different servers running Windows Server 2012 OS.
I can't test that server anymore, our company rewrote everything made made with gRPC to use ASP.NET Core & SignalR instead.
Yeah, no changes on the status of the retry code.  I'm hoping we can get back to it toward the end of this year, but we'll see what happens.

I wanted to give a quick update, I can get these stream removed errors to happen in our environment while sending some load combined with kicking servers. It becomes especially easy to repro using one of our stress tests which is:

1 Stress client (secure credentials)
5 back-end servers
1 L4 LB in between them

May be related and perhaps even partially the cause (maybe I am doing naughty things here) that to ensure the backend machines got to spread the load I created multiple clients/channels and round robin through them internally in the test tool. I send around 2k TPS, and I start to see these errors happen whenever servers Shutdown - usually coupled with some Internal/GOAWAY RpcExceptions as well. The retry interceptor we use can catch these and make them invisible to the client, but I have seen this special one pop up from time to time when our retry interceptor tries to salvage the original call:

```
System.ObjectDisposedException: Safe handle has been closed
   at System.Runtime.InteropServices.SafeHandle.DangerousAddRef(Boolean& success)
   at System.StubHelpers.StubHelpers.SafeHandleAddRef(SafeHandle pHandle, Boolean& success)
   at Grpc.Core.Internal.ChannelSafeHandle.CreateCall(CallSafeHandle parentCall, ContextPropagationFlags propagationMask, CompletionQueueSafeHandle cq, String method, String host, Timespec deadline, CallCredentialsSafeHandle credentials)
   at Grpc.Core.Internal.AsyncCall`2.CreateNativeCall(CompletionQueueSafeHandle cq)
   at Grpc.Core.Internal.AsyncCall`2.Initialize(CompletionQueueSafeHandle cq)
   at Grpc.Core.Internal.AsyncCall`2.UnaryCallAsync(TRequest msg)
   at Grpc.Core.Calls.AsyncUnaryCall[TRequest,TResponse](CallInvocationDetails`2 call, TRequest req)
   at Grpc.Core.DefaultCallInvoker.AsyncUnaryCall[TRequest,TResponse](Method`2 method, String host, CallOptions options, TRequest request)
   at Grpc.Core.Interceptors.InterceptingCallInvoker.<AsyncUnaryCall>b__4_0[TRequest,TResponse](TRequest req, ClientInterceptorContext`2 ctx)
   at [Snip].RetryInterceptor.<>c__DisplayClass14_0`2.<AsyncUnaryCall>b__1(Task _) in RetryInterceptor.cs:line 78
```

Both my client and server are C#, running on Windows 10, 1.18 but we'll try 1.19 soon.
